There was nothing wrong with your entry. This is a "from" or "away" trade where you are trading "away" from the 4H stochastic. What you are looking for is the 15M to be leading a price move upwards and everything to follow.  
  
This is a classic signature that the 15M is too weak and price is not following. It is a little hard to see when the 15M reaches 76.4 but we should be worried that the 1H hasn't come near or crossed 23.6 yet. When the 15M falls we are looking at "elasticity" and the 15M is likely to snap back down to the 1H and 4H area. By the time the 30M turns and reaches 23.6 again this trade is well done and we should be out.  
  
With 15M/30M trades we should see a pretty rapid 1-5 pip net gain. If the 15M doesn't go into over bought, the 30M is hardly rising and the 1H/4H are still over sold...gravity will take it's course and suck the 15M back down again.  
  
When running a long trade like this...treat it first like a scalp trade trying to net 5 pips and if you don't see that little bit of gain then start to worry....especially if we get into -15 to -20. If price had been moving long the 30M would have gone up to around 50 when the 15 hit 76.4 and we would have expected to see the some pull happening...but none here.  
  
Another tool to use is the 5M.....odds are it was over sold when the 15M started to fall or that the 5M went over sold on the 15M fall.....without the 5M turning up...the 15M is doomed to fall.

Actually the "14" wasn't a calculated number but rather equilibrium was a surprising result in studying the statistical data of using the 14,3,3 stochastic. If weird things happen frequently and consistently enough then they become a tool.  
  
I'm not going to leap to far into the 76.4, 78.6 or 80 debate. Other than my Vulcan mind partitions like that 76.4+23.6 = 100. Having said that, I can find no statistical difference of any relevance over the long run of using 80%, or 76.4% as a signal level. I haven't measured 78.6% but I would assume that just about any number between 76% and 80% would work.   
  
However, beyond that I'd rather just keep it simple and go with what I use. If someone wants to produce the data on 78.6 versus 76.4 or 80 I'm wide open for seeing the results. From observation and experience (which may be wrong) I can't anticipate there is much difference over the long run be it 76.4%, 78.6% or 80%.  
  
I used to use 5,3,3 exclusively then tried 14,3,3 with 5,3,3 but found that with MTF using both 5,3,3 and 14,3,3 was redundant. The 14,3,3 provided a little less noise and ultimately I have been converted to using 14,3,3. To me...14,3,3 on a 5M chart is much more accurate than using 5,3,3 and 14,3,3 on a 15M chart.

I been tinkering with several new stochastic indicators, one of them dealing with elasticity. My goal is to have a method of trying to determine the strength of a stochastic move that is more relative to pip movement than as a percentage.   
  
As we know, stochastics provide the location of price relative to a range within the stochastic period. However, we don't know what that range is at a quick glance or how that range is moving, shrinking, expanding in relation to the stochastic value. For example, is a 98%-76.4% stochastic move weaker or stronger in a narrow price range compared to a wider price range?  
  
If anyone is working on something similar I'd be interested in comparing notes.

I knew we'd come to this some day. First, unless someone can prove to me otherwise with statistical data (I've run my own), there is absolutely no difference with 76.4 and 23.6 versus 80/20 in terms of signals. The selection of 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 is for our brains to visualize a signal point.  
  
Having said that, the presentation here of selecting a fixed trading signal level like 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 is for simplification rather than trying to explain the nuances of anticipating a stochastic line that is a few points away from the 80 line on a closing candle. Signal levels are reference lines.  
  
The reality is that most of the trade signals upon close of a candle are much higher and much lower than 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 because the stochastic moves much further during the candle move.  
  
In MTF trading it is the movement of the stochastics that should be our signal and how the stochastics line up not the reference lines. But to write nuances in forum is, I believe an impossible task.  
  
I would agree with you that many traders use 80/20 because those are the default numbers, however I would certainly bet that 99% of the trades are made with stochastics "off" the exact 80 or 20 level simply due to the way the stochastic ends up.  
  
My thread theory is really teaching the nuances of stochastic moves ...I just don't want anyone to know that....oops! In MTF stochastics, the 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 lines are reference lines. The "safe" trading uses the reference lines....but the best trading comes before the reference lines are hit and the market is almost always moving before the reference lines get hit.  
  
None of MTF Stochastics is really about 80/20...it could as easily be about 79/21 or 81/19.  
  
For what percentage over the long run the impact of using 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 will have on our trading is nil. Just as equally as missing some trades with using 76.4/23.6 vs 80/20 we will also gain the advantage of waiting for some trades using 76.4/23.6. If we understand the nuances of stochastic moves the signal levels become even less important other than to understand that stochastics are over bought or over sold.  
  
More traders will lose trades on bad stop loss setups and exits then they ever will on signal levels.   
  
So, use 80/20 if you think it is better. Use 76.4/23.6 if you think it makes more logic mathematically and use 79/21, 81/19 if you are a free spirit or a rebel. None of it will matter in the long run.   
  
The two charts below show that not a single major move was made at 80/20 or 76.4/23.6 on EURUSD 4H from May 11-July 6...however all the nuances of stochastic moves caught every major move. I know hard to see in the pic below, check it out.  
  
I'm not saying you are wrong in what you say TEB, I'm just saying in the scheme of things it really won't make any difference to us as small traders if we use 80/20 or 76.4/23.6.

If you are in short on USDCAD be aware that there is speculation that intervention may occur between 1.03 and 1.04 with tomorrow's announcement, should the pair dip that low.  
  
Sentiment is that there will be an exponential drive to bring the USDCAD down to 1.00 if the currency should drop any significant amount (say below 1.03). This is likely to cause intervention by either or both banks to prop the pair up and prevent such a move. A sudden drop in USDCAD could significantly hurt Canada's manufacturing industry and Canada's economy.  
  
Watch for any hawkish rhetoric coming from Canada's news tomorrow. Such rhetoric would signal more rate increases in the future and likely put a lot of downward pressure on the USDCAD.  
  
Also, watch for a spike up before the downward fall. Stops should be higher than 1.06.   
  
If Canada does not raise its rate (unlikely), then have a quick exit plan.  
  
Have fun, should be a blast!

Hi Spud,  
  
Thanks so much for the posts you have contributed regarding MTF Stochs. Your experience and wisdom is immediately apparent. Your very presence gives everyone who reads this thread more courage.   
  
I have been very interested in looking at the Forex market from a Long therm time frame for awhile now. In back testing the weekly stochastic swings on GBP/USD, and using the daily chart to time the entry, the number of pips gained would make anyone want to trade that way... I have used the rally beginning in early April, 2006 - the present to back test.   
  
On this attached chart, I show a 2 period RSI overlaid onto a 5,3,3 Stochastic. Once the Stoch is OB or OS, sell or buy the next bar AFTER the RSI crosses the Stochastic Indicator. The circles indicate those times since April, '06. Total pips is 4,019 with the highest gain of 1,341 pips and the lowest gain of 70 pips. In 66 weeks to the present, the gain is 60 pips per week. There are no losses.  
  
When approaching an OB or OS level on the Stochastic, if I switch to the daily chart, the entries and exits are much better and the gain nearly doubles... again no losses.  
  
My question then is In your opinion, could one contemplate trading this with a real account or is this a classic case of the back test always looking good and in a forward test, a minefield may lie ahead.  
  
Thanks again!

Hi Quick,  
  
80/20, 76.3/23.6 Both seem fine... given a choice, I would go with the fib #'s though...  
  
The exit is the reverse of the entry... as the Stochastic reaches the overbought territory, switch to the 1 day chart, or the 4 hr for that matter and follow the Stochastic as Spud has instructed earlier in this thread... The shorter the time frame, the more you may want to wait a bit beyond the initial cross.  
  
Once you are in the trade, wait and follow the 1 week stochastic until it hits oversold territory then again switch back to the 1 day or 4 hr and find your entry there... a trade could last 2 - 5 or 6 weeks on the outside.  
  
I'm using the benefit of the longer time frame to filter out my own emotions and try to grow an account... on paper it looks good.. as Spud kindly suggested, now it's time to try some actual money... I may go with a micro lot to start with though!

Hi XXXXXX, when IYA came out with the #MTF Stochastic I watched it carefully against the separate Stochastics on different time frames. As long as you keep the different options on the lowest time frame chosen (in my case I utilize the M15 chart) the end points and the angle arriving there will be correct. So I now use a single M15 chart with the following:  
  
Time Frame = 15, KPeriod 14, 3, 3  
Time Frame = 30, KPeriod 14, 3, 3  
Time Frame = 60, KPeriod 5, 3, 3  
Time Frame = 60, KPeriod 14, 3, 3  
Time Frame = 240, KPeriod 14, 3, 3  
  
I basically trade off the H1 time frame but when nearing known fib levels for entry or exit I will drop down to M15 for trade ONLY if the majority of the Stochastics are tight or leading one another perfectly. I'm sure Spud would tell you the key to trading is consistency. This is a good system where the statistics are in your favor. I even uitilize increased leverage after a losing trade. I'll try to post this along with a picture on the forum.  
  
EDIT: the 800 EMA on median for the M15 chart is the 200 EMA median on the H1, the other 2 MA's I am not really using. A friend asked me to watch them to see what I thought.

Hi k2kv,  
  
I am sure I remember spud saying, he places stops only as an emergency measure, usually 50-80 pips away, and moves them as market moves etc. His exit is based on what the stochs say and their direction, eg if u r in because of 4h stochs crossing down from 80, and price goes against him, i think he stays in till stoch cross back up past 80.   
  
My take with this system is, that it is more impt to get the right direction, rather than the right price. There will be drawdowns, but if ur direction is right, it will go where the stochs r pointing. If stoch direction changes, u can come out with a small enough loss. I think it is extremely hard to get an entry precise enough to keep dd down to below 15 pips. Esp on a 30M or 1H chart.   
  
Am sure he will correct me if this is incorrect.   
  
Cheers,

Jeff: This might be getting a bit off-topic, but I know that exits are crucial to being profitable as a trader, and I'm still wrestling with the stop/TP issues myself, trying to find a good balance. Here's some excellent advice that I wish I had gotten and taken earlier, before wiping out my account 3 times!: start off with a micro account - [Oanda](/brokers/oanda "View OANDA Broker Profile") is good, as you can set any size lots - until you start to get consistently profitable. Risking $5 is nowhere near as freaky as risking $50 or $500! Of course, you won't make a massive amount either, but as long as you can get the consistency, you can work up to that.   
I think that yes, Spud is only using set stops as a catastrophe measure, and that is all well and good if you (a) are confident about your analysis, and (b) are watching the market more or less continuously (if you are trading off a 4 hour chart, maybe you can get by with only checking at the close of the candle, but that is still an awful lot of risk, as far as I am concerned! It is also ok if you are using a scalping strategy, like the one you learned first - I think this is why people go for scalping methods, as you can go to sleep (or to work) with a calm mind, being out of the market. I have found that a 40-50 pip risk works for me - but then I want to either take the same in profit, or else make sure that my accuracy rate is high enough to cover the times when the stop gets hit. Myself, I am still playing with this, but I am getting better. Using a micro account helps, and also it helps to take smaller profits while you are building up confidence (I know lots of people talk about letting your profits run, and that is all well & good, but Spud has a great philopsophy on this too!) You should find that setting smaller TP will increase your hit rate...  
Well, I hope that is all IMHO but hope it helps....

I'm trading USDCAD purely on the reasoning I expect CAD to go par or better against the USD before year end. Didn't look at charts as I'm in this for the long haul. Every time the USD goes up to 1.06 or higher you can bet I'm adding shorts to new highs.  
  
You are right, fundamentally the USD has no business rising against the CAD and the current short term climb after the rate announcement was somewhat expected because so much pressure downwards in anticipation was created beforehand. Everything the US has to cope with over the next 12 months from Iraq, Iran, the US election, interest rates, etc. is all a benefit to Canada. Anything that spells tragedy in oil is a boom for Canada. Housing in Canada is likley to set record prices in 2007 and this will keep pressure up on inflation with low unemployment, high gas prices, and high housing prices...so CAD has no choice but to probably raise rates to 5%. The US can't raise rates for obvious reasons. Just flip through the indicator check list on USD vs CAD and you see nothing but -'ves on US side and +'ves on CAD side.  
  
So, take the up moves in USDCAD as opportunity to make more money and leave lots of room for volatility.

Hey everyone,  
  
I just want to start off saying "THANK YOU" to Spudfyre for this fabulous thread and his amazing generosity in sharing his knowledge with the rest of us. Through his incredibly hard work and amazing selflessness, the rest of us struggling with trading can reap the benefits.  
  
I'm sure I am like a lot of you who have struggled to find a system that is simple, elegant, and allows you to make profits consistently. Much to my chagrin, I have spent THOUSANDS on books, DVDs, software programs, data feeds, etc. over the last two years. What I have gained from all of that is thousands of dollars lost in my account, and nearly blowing out my original $5000 starting balance. I understand it is the lot of many traders to lose their accounts more than once before it finally "clicks" for them, but that is very little consolation when you see your dwindling balance.  
  
What an amazing find this thread is, though. I just found it on Wednesday of last week, and I was more than a little daunted by the fact that there were over 1020 posts! I was determined to make it through all the posts and I am now officially caught up with all of them (It only took me four days!)  
  
I wanted to share with everyone my first three trades with Spudfyre's system because they were so effortless. On all three of them I just waited for the 15/30/60 stochs to be lined up and crossing the same direction at the same time. I set my TP at 20 pips, and never sweated once. On the first and second trades, the 15 min stoch started retracing and that would have freaked me out previously. I wasn't worried at all, however, because the 60 min stoch had good angle and separation between the %K and %D lines. The third trade was over so fast that the market didn't even have a chance to retrace!  
  
The really neat thing is that all three trades happened within a 12 hour period. Actually, there was a fourth trade on the EUR/JPY that also hit 20 pips, but I didn't include the charts. The bottom line is that I have never made 80 pips so quickly and easily as I did this last Thursday night into Friday morning.   
  
Thanks again, Spud. I really feel like this MTF trading is going to be the answer to my personal mystery of forex trading success. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Believe me, I understand the internal struggle and the lack of confidence and the gut twisting fear that comes along with learning how to trade. It can be really painful, at times. The real secret is learning patience and discipline to WAIT FOR THE SETUP. That has been the hardest part for me. Spud has even made mention of it on this thread that it is soooo dangerous to jump the gun out of fear of missing the trade. There will ALWAYS be another trade. Wait for the close of the candle. Jeff,  
  
By angle and separation all I am talking about is when I looked at the H1 stochastics, the %K line had a nice steep angle down and it was well separated from the %D line. The lines were running parallel to each other and not even coming close to converging. What that told me was that even though the M15 had crossed back up, the move was not significant at all because that retracement on the M15 had no effect whatsoever on the H1 stochastic. On the H1 chart, the downtrend was still strong and intact, so I could ride out the retracement with little worry. In addition to looking at the strength of the H1 stochastic, I also applied a fibonacci retracement to the M15 chart and realized that the retracement came right to the 61.8% level. The GBP/JPY pair moves a lot (as we all know) and when it retraces it often retraces back to 61.8% before continuing it's trend. That was another piece of information that, again, gave me the confidence to ride out the retracement and trust that the downtrend would continue.  
  
So, by angle I mean the steepness of the %K line, and by separation I mean the relationship between the %K and %D line. I like to use both lines on the stochastics indicator, that's why I don't have all the different stoch timeframes in one window. Eight different lines is too confusing. I just keep a separate chart open for each TF so that I can see the candle formation in that TF, as well as the stoch for that TF.  
  
And you're right when you point out that you don't remember that being discussed on this board before. Examing the angle and separation of the %K and %D lines is just my own personal method of judging the strength and solidity of the stochastics trend.   
  
Good luck.

Do you wait for the candle to close on _only_ the smallest time frame you're watching? And, do you always wait for your candles to close before exiting as well as when entering?

Sorry, Jeff. I didn't see this first question.   
  
Okay, here's what I personally mean by waiting for the close of the candle. I know that Spud would say, if you are trying to coordinate the 15/30/60 stochs to wait for the close of the 60 minute bar. If, on the close of the 60m bar the 60m stoch closes below 76.4, then the 15m stoch and 30m stoch should be well below 76.4 and the entry signal is confirmed.  
  
I, on the other hand, tend to take entry a little sooner. I have spent a lot of time (and money) to learn a lot about candlestick formations. Consequently, many times candlestick formations will give you an early warning of a turn in the stochastics, so entry (while riskier) is less risky than it otherwise might be. For example: in the first trade I posted, I was looking at the 15 minute bars. Two bars BEFORE my entry bar there was a shooting star formation. That is a classic candlestick reversal pattern. When I saw that, and then saw the m15 stoch close below 50 with the 30m stoch crossed and heading down and the H1 stoch converging, I went ahead and pulled the trigger. It wasn't the safest entry possible, but the candlestick patterns on the m15 chart gave a really strong early warning for me. The close below 50 on the M15 stoch, combined with the cross on the H30 stoch and the convergence on the H1 stoch was all I personally needed for entry.  
  
I hope that helps. If you want to learn from the best source of candlestick patterns, get "Japanese Candlestick Charting Techniques" by Steve Nison. It is the bible of candlestick charts.

On the M15 chart, the two bars that preceded my entry bar were a textbook bullish harami formation. That formation followed by the fact that on the close of the next bar the m15 stoch closed above 23.6 and the M30 had crossed its signal line and the H1 was converging was, again, all I personally needed to confirm the entry.  
  
I still waited for a stochastics close above 23.6, but I didn't feel I needed all three timeframes to close above it. All I felt I needed was a close above on M15 and to have the M30 and H1 to be moving that direction. The combination of the strong candlestick reversal pattern with the close above 23.6 on the M15 and the rising patterns on M30 and H1 were sufficient for me.  
  
It is riskier, though. Read Nison's book and truly get comfortable with the patterns before trading off of them. If you don't feel 100% with them, then follow Spud's advice and wait for a close of the H1 stoch to confirm the move. That is definitely the most conservative and safest approach.

I really would reccomend picking up Nison's book. I have perused Bigalow's books and his website, and I'm sure there is valuable information in them, but Nison was the originator. He is the one who brought candlestick patterns to the western world. He is the one that did the early research and had all of the Japanese books translated, and then spent years interpreting them. He is as close to the source as you can possibly get, and most other candlestick books quote him. So why not go to the source?  
  
He also has just released a fabulous profiting in forex DVD series that focuses exclusively on candlestick patterns in the forex and how they are a little different than the stock markets. It's very pricy, though. I was able to pick it up for about 1/2 off in a pre-release special. It is really good information, but you can learn 95% of what is in the DVD series just by getting his first book and using a little deductive reasoning. If you get his book, read it, and have questions on how to apply it to the forex, just send me a PM and I'll explain/illuminate what I can.  
  
Sorry, Spud. I didn't mean to get this far off topic in your forum. My only point was that candlesticks can aid in the MTF Stochastics approach. A reversal candle pattern confirmed by a stochastics close above 23.6 or below 76.4 is just another way to be more confident in the entry.  
  
So now let's get back to MTF Stochastics.....

Ian,  
  
Well, I have something to admit about all four of the trades that I posted my charts for: I didn't consult the 4hr at all. Actually, that's not true. For both the GBP/JPY and the EUR/JPY, the 4hr stochastic was firmly overbought and moving nearly horizontally. Consequently, there was no real trend from the 4hr to go with. Now, had the 4hr stochastics been moving below 76.4, then I would have wanted to trade in that direction. But, to me, whenever the stochastics are flattened out at either extremely overbought or extremely oversold, we then have a ranging market. At that point, all I was looking for was the 15/30/60 to be lined up together and that happens a LOT more often.   
  
On that first trade, the chart doesn't show it, but at the start of the Asian session, price had been moving down steadily. It then began a retracement up and it was at the height of that retracement, when the 15/30/60 started to turn back over that I got into the first trade. So, given the fact that the trend was already down for the asian session, I didn't worry about getting into a short when the 15 had just risen back above the 50% mark. As far as the shooting star goes, you're absolutely right. The candle wasn't very big, but you have to consider the candle in context:  
  
1) the trend had already been established as going down  
2) price was in a retracement off the initial down move, and that shooting star came right in at the 61.8% retracement level. This is a HUGE confluence even though the candle wasn't very long.  
3) the candle right after the shooting star closed below the close of the shooting star.  
4) the second candle after the shooting star was a STRONG down candle (one that opened near the high and closed near the low) that also coincided with a stochastics close below 50% continuing the downward move.  
  
Taking all of those factors together, I thought the trade was relatively safe.  
  
I hope that helps explain my reasoning.

If you are using the latest version by IYA, then it is pretty good. But obviously for the longer timeframes whose current bars have not yet closed, the the value of the indicator is going to change - since it is bades upon the Close of the bar.  
Thus if as used by SPUDFYRE, you place it (repeatedly into the same window on a 15 Min chart and edit it so it displays the 30min Stochastic, the 60min Stcohastic and the 240min stochastic) then for the 30,60 and 240 stochs it may/will repaint if their current bars did not close with the 15min bar. This is usually only a problem for the 60 and 240min timeframes. But the huge advantage when trading based on MTF stochastics is that you can see all 4 of them on the same screen.

If you are referring to my indicator, please go to the next link:

](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1448970&postcount=1460)As you may have read there are plenty of possibilities using this indicator.  
You can choose your own stochastic parameters (14,3,3, or 5,3,3, or whatever you like..).  
You only have to use **one** chart. Always choose the one with the smallest TF you want to use in your trading with stochastics.   
Then you can determine which TF stochastics you want to use, etc.  
If you switch to a higher TF, the stochastics of the lower TF's will disappear, but come back as soon as you switch back to the lower ones.   
You can determine how many TF's must be in sync to switch on the Alert. It's up to you.  
I would suggest that you first play with this indicator.

Hi Stochasters...!  
  
Here is another screenshot from my Multi-time frame Stochastic MT4 Screen...  
  
I have been most interested in working with daily charts, specifically GBP/USD... My strategy is to trade the daily chart only when the weekly stochastic is OB or OS... As the weekly begins to cross, enter long or short as the daily stoch (blue and yellow) cross...  
  
Ignore the daily until the OB/OS range is reached on the weekly.  
  
This system has produced 2,031 pips since the entry on March 8th, until the exit on July 26...   
  
Comments?

Hi Tom.  
  
The only thing I noticed is that at the oversold level on the weekly, the 28 gets hit more consistently in an up market than the 20 and the holds for a down market... The 75 or so might be better... It is important to check out your particular pair and do your own observations.   
  
The MA's on my chart are the 144 ema and the 200 ema. In an up trending market, when the weekly stoch is bottoming out, chances are high that price will touch down briefly on the 144, then bounce and resume the up trend as the stoch rises... that is until the main weekly trend is broken... On the cable, we have been in a steady uptrend for the past 16 months.

It would be great if you could explain how I might do this, or where I'm going wrong with the indicators.  
  
Thanks[/quote]  
  
Hello,  
  
I am using the stochastic from the weekly applied to the daily and entering with the daily. both are combined into one chart using the #MTF Stochastic Indicator.   
  
1\. Drag the #MTF Stoch indicator onto your daily chart. Use 10080 time frame as your period (1 Week)  
  
2\. Drag the #MTF Stoch indicator onto the weekly stoch indicator window and choose 1440 (daily) as the time frame. Change the colors and weights of your lines....   
  
That's it!  
  
This forum is devoted to exploring how to put 4 timeframes in one window... most commonly the 15 min, 1 hr, 30 min and 4 hr .   
  
In seeing the "big picture" one can have greater insight into understanding the market before entering a trade.

Hello pip,![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Rainbow is my guarantee that the trend is run to my favour.  
See the completeness color of it, that is the direction of the trend.  
  
The decision to enter trade is still by MTF stoch,   
The rainbow can save our trade if we got a wrong entry.   
When this happen, wait until the rainbow to complete the full flip to make sure the trend is wrong and the trade need to Stop loss.  
Because fault entry by MTF stoch. is not always fault in trend.

Jeff,  
  
I have been exactly where you are now. Over the last several weeks, I have had to learn quite a few painful lessons about exercising patience with this system. When you get the right entry, it should very rarely, if ever, go negative on you. I have attached a slide to show what I mean, and illustrate a common mistake I have made too many times recently, but will not make again.  
  
As you see the slide, all the stochs are beneath 20 and turning up. At the point where the M15 stoch crosses 20, there is a really nice Morning Star candle pattern, which is a reversal pattern. Notice that the M30 stochs are pointing up but they have not crossed 20 yet. Over the past several weeks, based on the M15 cross, the strong candle pattern, and the fact that the M30 stochs are pointing up, I would have gone long. Anyone who did that, however, had the position turn around on them and go negative by roughly 300 pips. Sadly, I have been burned by this a LOT in the past several weeks.   
  
Now that I have learned my lesson, though, I knew to not get tempted by the initial M15 cross, as the M30 hadn't crossed yet. I know, now, that if the M15 crosses 20 way before M30 does, that the M15 will turn back down and then the second upturn in M15 is the one that will pull the M30 up over 20 and signal the real move. So that's what I waited for. When I got the right entry, I made 124 pips in about 20 minutes, and it didn't go negative on me once.  
  
Spud is oh so correct when he mentioned over an over again to WAIT until M15 & M30 were out of the 80/20 zones.  
  
Good luck. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

In my way of thinking this depends on  
\- how many pips are you trying to earn each time. The more you want the greater likelihood of an unpleasant drawdown.  
\- what is the risk ratio of your trade relative to your account size. The smaller it is the more drawdown you may be able to tolerate.  
\- what is the daily volatility swing or daily range  
\- what are the characteristics of the pair you trade - some pairs are erratic and others are a smoother back and forth price action.  
\- how much are you willing to lose. in other words, what loss can you sustain and not reduce your ability to trade at the risk ratio level you are now.  
  
hope that helps.

Jeff, that's exactly where I have been the last several weeks: at the drawing board. After some quick early success with this system, I got waaaayyy too cocky and, as Spud has admitted himself, I began to think that I could predict what the stochastics were going to do. Consequently, I made tremedously huge errors getting into trades way too early and wound up paying for it.   
  
So I have been quiet while I got my head together and learned how to wait for the trade to come to me. You know what's interesting, though... There are so many different trading systems out there, and any one of them can produce good solid results. No one system is really better than any other. What it really all boils down to is the trader himself. If a trader has mastered himself and can exercise the patience and discipline to wait for the optimum setup from whatever system he chooses to follow, then he will be successful long term. Without patience and discipline, even the most effective trading system will lead to numerous losses.   
  
I think I have the patience now. We'll see as we get into next week....

> Quick question for anyone.... when determining the trend with the 1h or 4h do you use the 5stoch or 14stoch? I have not had to decide which to use until this morning when the 5stoch lead the 14stoch quite a ways.

Personally, I have both the 5 and the 14 on my charts for three different timeframes: 15, 30, and H1. The relationship between the 5 and the 14 can be a tricky one but an easy way to think of it is that the 5 is the short term trend and the 14 is the longer trend. When the 5 pulls away from the 14, it *usually* means that it price is just making a temporary pull away from the longer trend, and will *usually* snap back to the longer trend. When the two move together, it is a very powerful signal. In fact, I usually look for that as my ideal setup: the 5 & 14 either above 80 or below 20 and turning together. That's just about the safest entry possible.   
  
You should study the chart I attached. I have highlighted some of the patterns that I look for. I use the 14 as my indicator of the trend, and I use the 5 to either confirm that we are moving in the direction of the trend (when they are both moving together), or are in a countertrend pullback (when the 5 pulls quickly away from the 14).  
  
In the end, the interpretation is more art than science and it takes a lot of practice. Like Spud says -- spend hours watching the charts (without trading) to get a feel for how the stochastics move together.

I'm a realtive nubie to this thread, but I have a couple years experience in the markets.  
  
This post is for those of you reading who want to know how big to make your trades...  
  
Simple Formula: (Account Balance) / [(Number Losses Until Broke) * (1-for mini, 10-for standard) * (Max Pip Loss on Single Loss)]  
  
For Example: a person with 1000 wanting no more than 2% risk on any worst trade would have 50 trades in there account or (50) perfect losses until broke. 1000 * .02 = 20. 1000 / 20 = 50. They would probably be on a mini account, so (1). Max pip loss lets say (50), i think that was Spud's initial stop loss... So 1000 / [50*1*50] = .4. So each trade should be .4 mini lots.  
  
When I first began I didnt really understand the limits of leverage until i read some random book and it helped me to make apropriately sized trades...  
Hope this is helpful

Mtrmth,  
  
"The dragging part is out." Why?? I have used the Alpari demo and dragging is the same as with every other MT4 program. Did you follow my instructions above, and _try_ to drag the indicator?  
  
When you save a chart as a template, it then becomes available to you when you want to replicate it on one of your chart windows. In other words, after you've saved a template, you can then open a new chart window and apply that template (or any other template you might have saved) to it by right-clicking and selecting templates. Choose the template of your choice and your chart will reflect your selection.  
  
Your new charts will open with NO template. However, you can save your workspace by clicking on file ->save as. Give it a name. Next time you boot up, your last-saved workspace will show up, and all your charts will be in place.   
  
Good luck! 

Jeff Singer, K2KV

I suspect your 15 had already turned down and crossed back below 76.4. I believe the conservative approach according to the rules suggests you get out when the 15 first hits the 76.4. If you do stay in, once it crosses back through 76.4, it's time to flee.  
  
Also, the fact that the 1H had not yet come up to around 50 or so when the 30M was overbought infers that the move was weak (this, from Spud, when I asked a very similar question a few weeks ago!).  
  
I must caution that I am also fairly new at this with many questions of my own; other, more experienced traders may offer a more informed explanation. It's fairly quiet here during the day, just wanted to give you a quick reply.  
  
Hope that helps...

Bundubill,  
  
Without a posting of what your charts looked like, I'd have to agree with Jeff here. Based on what you said, I do believe that the M15 and M30 were already too overbought. While I know the rules say to enter the trade when all three are pointing the same direction, the ideal (and most profitable) setups will have M15, M30, and H1 all crossing out of the 80/20 zone at about the same time. Usually M15 will lead, M30 will cross within the next 15-30 minutes, and H1 should be crossing at the same time, or just about to cross. If M15 and M30 pull quickly away from H1, so that M15 and M30 have already gone overbought by the time that H1 is just getting out of oversold, then that is a sign of a very weak move.

Hi Spuds and all,  
Thank you all for a very informative thread. I have been working my way through it for several weeks and have been able to improve my trading results because of it. I don't know if anyone still uses the Big Stochastic, created by Skyline, but I have found it very helpful. I have modified the original version and offer it in the hope others will find it useful. The mods are: displays four definable time frames, has input for sto period, has alert when two adjoining time frames of the three higher are both > 61.8 and rising or below 38.2 and falling, and has added colors - Blue for > 68.2 & rising - Red for < 38.2 and falling - Gold for > 80 or < 20 and Black for all other conditions. I look forward to the continuing education this thread is providing.  
  
Enjoy and Happy Pipping to all.

> 
> Personally, I have both the 5 and the 14 on my charts for three different timeframes: 15, 30, and H1. The relationship between the 5 and the 14 can be a tricky one but an easy way to think of it is that the 5 is the short term trend and the 14 is the longer trend. When the 5 pulls away from the 14, it *usually* means that it price is just making a temporary pull away from the longer trend, and will *usually* snap back to the longer trend. When the two move together, it is a very powerful signal. In fact, I usually look for that as my ideal setup: the 5 & 14 either above 80 or below 20 and turning together. That's just about the safest entry possible.   
>    
>  You should study the chart I attached. I have highlighted some of the patterns that I look for. I use the 14 as my indicator of the trend, and I use the 5 to either confirm that we are moving in the direction of the trend (when they are both moving together), or are in a countertrend pullback (when the 5 pulls quickly away from the 14).  
>    
>  In the end, the interpretation is more art than science and it takes a lot of practice. Like Spud says -- spend hours watching the charts (without trading) to get a feel for how the stochastics move together.
>

First of all I must give much credit and appreciation to Spuds for his wonderful work and devotion to this thread. It's made me a successful trader indeed.  
  
It is NOT my desire to change anything Spud's creates, and I am only throwing out for anyone interested a change I made for creating exit points that has worked very well indeed for me. I primarily started using this instead of the Fibonacci levels Spud uses on his break-out systems, and have since incorporated it into all of Spud's strategies and like I said, it works well for me indeed by keeping a couple of hundred extra pips in my pocket every week.  
  
I have always had trouble with Fib retracements, and just have never found them accurate enough to place my pips on the table chasing them. Hey - that's just me. I cut my teeth in on trading with Pivot Points and that's what I am comfortable with in deciding what level my trade may go to and what level to exit (before I get chastised too much I MOST DEFINITELY use Spud's 80/20 rule also.)  
  
I watch the pivot point levels, and so frequently you will see price hit a R/S level and retrace. Once it hits a S/R level and starts to retrace either with that candle or the next I then exit the trade. If it once again returns in my favor I re-enter the trade.   
  
This has saved me boucoup pips in my account that I haven't given back because I'm out of a bounce early.   
  
And please - no comments that PP ARE nothing more than FIB lines. I've been in this forex market way too long! If this works for you a little better visually, then great - I'm glad I could contribute something to this wonderful thread. If it doesn't - that's OK too. We're all individuals and one man's meat is another man's whatever.  
  
When the stochs are above 76.4 I closely monitor where price is in relation to the nearest resistance line; if below 23.6 I watch the next lower support line. When price hits a S/R line this 'usually' is sufficient advanced warning that saves me some pips in exiting the trade.  
  
If you want to check this out just add a pivot point calculator to your arsenal and put the pivot points on your charts. PP Calculators are all over the place and they're free.  
  
Here's just one place you can get one for your charts  
<http://www.tradejuice.com/pp.html>

Spud, I don't know if you are ever coming back, but I want everyone else to know your system is solid. I took another escalator ride last night. Got in to the GBP/JPY @ 7 pm CST @ 233.68, looking for about 50-75 pips. The 15, 30, 1h and 4h were all at or breaking the 80. Closed out at 11 pm at 232.65. I had a feeling price was going to test 232.0, but I couldn't stay up to watch it. I still have a "real" job, but not for much longer, thanks to guys like you. Price dipped all the way to 231.75. Next time I'm on the escalator, I'll also be catching some of the retrace action using the 5m and the 15m. I could have added another 30-40 pips using the hedge, but I wasn't quite confident enough. After watching last night, I feel pretty good about the next time. Seems best to try and catch the retrace action early, as the movements seem bigger then and get smaller later. Kind of like waves getting smaller as they move away from the rock splash. I'm sure there is a way to make your system better, but it works pretty well as is. Thanks again and Happy Trading.

The initial trigger is the 4H stochastic line crossing either 20 (for a buy) or 80 (for a sell)... once the stochastic crosses these lines we wait until it starts going up/down again at which point once it crosses those lines (upwards from below 20 for a buy and downwards from above 80 for a sell), we start looking at the 3 other time frames; 15M, 30M and 1H in that order. We wait until those 3 are all going in the same direction (and the 4H should be also but im probably going to include it as well just to be safe) and then enter into the relevant trade right? stochastic15c = iStochastic(symbol, PERIOD_M15, kPeriod, dPeriod, slowing, MODE_SMA, 0, MODE_MAIN, 1);

Thanks for the kind words...  
  

have been making extremely short term trades to capture small pips. This I have been doing to demonstrate the use of stochastics over multiple time frames. I also wanted to demonstrate that you can make low gain pip trades and make a consistent income from it."_  
  
I teach at the college level, full time, I love my job, and have no desire to sit by a computer all day to trade. I wanted to see if using the idea of looking ahead to longer time frames beyond the daily would provide that same measure of seeing the big picture... just in a period of 4 -6 weeks per trade and reversal, rather than 4 - 6 trades per day!  
  
So in answer to your questions...  
  
1\. Correct... It really is a weekly trade system, using the daily for entries only after the weekly stochastic is established in the OB/OS territory... the daily Stoch or BH Ergodic indicator I posted earlier acts as the trigger only at those OB/OS times... I try to ignore it during the middle of the run.  
  
2\. Actually I wrote a post on Aug 25th entitled "Weekly Swing Update", [http://www.forexfactory.com/showthre...06#post1558606](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?p=1558606#post1558606) , Where I posted a chart showing me going long on the GBP/USD... I am still long, even though the BH ERgodic has headed south as the weekly stoch is still in mid range, not in OB/OS territory. This is where I need the faith and patience the Weekly Stochastic helps reinforce.  
  
Agreed on the Snake Force Indicator! It does repaint... it is great for back testing but beware using it going forward.  
  
So... Really what I am relying on is the Weekly Stochastic. Everything else contributes noise... When I see the weekly go into OB/OS territory, only then do I pay attention to daily indicators to help as a trigger for reversals from long to short and the reverse.  
  
I agree about the potential for large draw downs... In back testing, the worst case I found going back on the Cable has been 150 pips. As a simplified money management plan, I would trade 1 lot for each $5,000 of balance... and no stops! Mind you, this is on a demo account for now. I want to run this forward for at least 6 months before I risk actual funds.  
  
This is still a work in progress! All comments are welcome!  
  
Good trading!

Thanks for answering my questions jnevins ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Well, I will try your method but trading only in daily chart (weekly is too much and very risky to me) once I have a confirmation from weekly stoch. I mean that if weekly stoch is OB or OS then I will trade with daily stoch only if daily stoch is also OB or OS in the same place and crossed the 80/20 point. While I see daily stoch going right to my desired direction without curving so much, then I will stay in that trade but the important point here is when to exit:  
  
I will exit the position in daily watching candle patterns (double top/button, hammer, spinning top...), support and resistances in high-low important points or simply raising the SL when I am gaining more than 100-150 pips, it can reverse only 100-150 to exit (or trailing the trade). The 28 EMA in daily chart also has a great indication to reverse, many more if it happens in an important point or candle pattern that it's also indicating a reverse (or even in fibonacci 50%), as it has been stated in a different trading method. If the daily stoch reach the other OB/OS zone I will exit the trade, in this case it would be the perfect trade.  
  
Do you exit only when your weekly stoch is OB or OS again?, as you know stoch can reverse in every moment to the opposite direction and it can make you lose a lot of pips trading in weekly.

Hey Guys,  
  
I was a close follower when Spud generously gave his time to this thread, and I stayed with it while he mentored each and every one of us on the specific details of his methods. No doubt, MTF Stochastics, with experience, can be a terrific method of trading. Spud was a great teacher and mentor, but he has obviously -- and sadly -- vanished from the scene. Hopefully he will return one day, but until he does, I'd like to continue to learn as much as I can. And, believe, me, I still have a great deal to learn.  
  
I've begun to lose interest in this thread (as I suspect from the lack of participation here, that many others have, as well), mainly because the focus here has dramatically shifted from TRADING with MTF Stochs, to running all kinds of supplemental indicators, writing brilliant code, endless EA's, auto-systems, and the like, but I personally don't prefer this route for my own trading experience. The current direction of the thread just seems to be way off-topic for me, though I certainly understand and respect the interest of others in these peripheral discussions.  
  
However, I'd like to gain a better grip on the actual trading process itself, and I truly want to learn the more subtle nuances of the MTF Stochastic methodology, so that I can become a better, more efficient -- and successful -- trader. This is not to say there is anything wrong with all the other stuff; I'm just saying that for me, personally, I'd like to get back to refining the core methodology.  
  
With that in mind, I'd like to suggest to others who may feel similarly, that we start either a brand new thread, or begin a more interactive trading or chat group (either on this site or elsewhere), specifically focused on _How to Trade MTF Stochs_. We could participate all day long if we like, and share our thoughts, charts, entries/exits, offer heads-up alerts regarding possible upcoming trades, figure out what we're doing wrong (and right!), and generally help each other to become better and more successful traders for the long term.  
  
It would be more of a "purist" group, not so involved in cluttering up our screens with endless auto-pilots and mechanical indicators (except, of course, for the most common basic pivot points, S&R lines, and perhaps a few MA's) so that we can concentrate on seriously honing our trading skills and learning how to utilize MTF Stochastics effectively (if not exclusively), in order to add many more pips to our daily diets.  
  
Anyone else interested in doing this with me?  
  
Thanks for reading! 

Jeff Singer, K2KV

So far most of my trades are elastic trades, where the 2 biggest stochs are already at the overbought or oversold region. Thus only the 15/30min stoch deviate away from those regions and then when they are going back to that regions, I place an order.   
  
However, I have made 2 trades that are based on all 4 stochs going the same direction. And they have netted me even higher profits.  
  
What I have observed is that when the stochs are closer together, the more stochs closer, the more the profits.  
  
I will update my blog again soon to include the 2 trades which boosted my account to 4k alr.  
  
So far, I have only suffered one lost, about 40pips lost. This was due to the stochs not being close together. Thus I think it is safest to only enter when 3 stochs are close together.

First I would like to thank Spudfyre for his most excellent trading method. Originally I found this thread, read through it, had some success with it and then left.   
  
Why?  
  
Well, I was a complete noob and totally impatient.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f606.png?v=15.1)  
  
I mean, who wants to wait around for the sun, moon and the heavens to all align just for a few pips?? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f634.png?v=15.1)  
  
Well after blowing my first account (cough!) and trying out several other methods and failing miserably with them, I've come back to the only system that has worked for me so far.  
  
Here is a trade I took today, nothing spectacular, just good steady pips.  
  
When I entered the trade, the 15m stoch was already to the 80 and the 30m was just past halfway towards the 80. I might have been able to get in earlier but the 30 had bounced around a bit, so their was some indecision on my part as to which way it was going to go.  
  
GBP/USD  
Entry was at the Green Horizontal Line: 1.9699  
Exit at the Red Horizontal Line: 1.9724  
(Spread Included)  
Pips Profit: 25  
  
Took An Earlier trade for +7 Pips   
Made my 20 for the day and 12 for the pip bank.  
  
Ron.

George Lane who originally designed the Stoch indicator for daily stock and/or commodity trading built it on the premise of what I call "tendency." He concluded after math analysis that price "tends" to close near their past highs (bull trend) or lows (bear trend). The Stoch or any other indicator would only be helpful once in a blue moon if "tendency" in our human existence did not exist. (if that were the case the only tendency would be pure randomness. If that were the case then we would not be posting, blogging or even trading.)  
  
In fact, despite the appearance of randomness in price "tendency" does exist. Tendency shows up in all areas of living.  
  
People tend to shop at the store or mall that is closest to them. Remember, "if you build it they will come." Advertisers know that people tend to respond better in groups. This is the tendency of the tribe. The same for the most part is true with price. Price tends to reach for a close that is typically of its current direction.   
  
Of course, eventually the current direction will change, but the "tendency" will simply continue in a different direction.  
  
The value of the MTF SToch is that it helps the trader observe the degree of "tendency." It is not fool proof, but is it a good barometer.  
  
If traders can get both a psychological and empirical hold on the significance of "tendency" then they will know how to use the Stoch to their best advantage. The novice trader is mostly looking for a cross over of the K and the D. That of course is neat and tidy on the chart, but it does not mean anything significant over the long term on a single time chart.

What I usually do is one of two things:  
  
A - wait for the 15M to turn over the 80/20 line along with either the 1H or the 30M (this set up I use for a short quick 5 to 30 pips)  
  
or   
  
B - wait for the 4H to turn over the 80/20 line when the 15M does (this set up can lead to long pips runs of 50 plus) It is even better if the 4H has agreement with at least two of the lower TFs.   
  
Even if you get a good signal on either option the trick is to enter at the right spot. Entering at the right price helps calm the psycho side of trading. I find it hard to hold on when price goes against me right away.

I use mtf stochs in the following way. I place trades when the 30 (gold) and 1hr (dark green) line up or down when moving past 20 and 80 respectively and then pay attention to the trades, most of the time you can bang out 30-100 pips per trade, and if the 4hr (red) and daily line up you can ride the pip train for days some times. I also use the stoch ropes on the same chart, I like the added color. The other indicator on the attached chart is the alligator, you don't trade when the alligator lines are tight together. Th alligator tends to keep you out of crappy trades where price does not really go anywhere. To me this is the simplest and most effective way to trade and be profitable.

Just be careful, because the MTF stochastic lags.   
If you plot in 15min TF the 1hour stochastic with MTF, you have to shift the 1hour MTF 3 bars to the right. The 240min stoch you have to shift the MTF 240min line 15bars to the right.  
Its because the time of the bar is in MetaTrader bound to the open, and not to the close. Compare the charts and you will see.  
  
Pay attention to this, because this could be very misleading at manual backtesting with the MTFstoch indicator.  
  
This problem have all versions of MTF indicators.

But anyway MTF strategy is great and if you take only the best signals (1-2/day) you have like 90% accuracy.

Well, look on charts, the time values you see down on the horisontal line are not times of closing of the bar, but OPENING the bar.  
So 15min bar at 14:00 means BAR WHICH OPENS AT 14:00 AND CLOSES AT **14:15.**  
So, if you on 15min chart wont to see closing of the 12:00 bar of the 4h timeframe, you have to go to the right and look on the 15:45 bar. ( which opens at 15:45 and closes at 16:00) BECAUSE 12:00bar on the 4HOUR chart OPENS at 12:00 bud CLOSES at 16:00.  
Take a look on charts, you will see what i'm saying.   
But the MTF indicator referst to the opening values. So the peak (according to previous pictures) at 15:00 on 1Hchart is not at 15:00 on the 15min chart but its at 15:45 bar.

As I look on your charts, you have same MTF indicator as me. So open any chart and look on the last (not finished yet) bar. And look down on the time on the time axis. - you will see this time is reffering to the opening of the bar, not close of the bar. And all other bars too.  
  
Then go to the 60min TF and find some nice sharp top or bottom of the 60min stochastic. Write down the time of the bar and **closing value** of the bar.  
Then go to the 15min TF and find there this top/bottom of the 60min MTF stochatic line. Right, now you see, **the time of the bar is the same**.  
But same doesnt means correct! Look on the closing value of this bar!   
Yes, its different. Because the **closing value of the 60min bar lies 3 bars to the right.** Check it!   
  
So. If on the 60min TF the stoch has bottom at 14:00 and then you look in the 15min TF, the bottom of the 60min stoch is on the 14:00 bar too. **BUT** , **it schould be on the 14:45 bar._Closing value of the 14:00 60min TF is the same as the closing value of the 14:45 15min TF bar._** Check it!   
  
Why? Because 14:00 on the 60min chart means bar which OPENS at 14:00 and closes at 15:00.   
And on the 15min TF at 14:45 is bar which OPENS at 14:45 and closes at 15:00.  
  
Play with the charts and you will see, that the time values at MTF indicator are correct, but not the placing of stochatic lines. ALL stochatic lines of the higher timeframes schould be shifted to the right. How much? It depends on the timeframe.

well, I think there is no way how to shift the MTFstoch lines. Only way is reprograming this indicator, probably.You are right, we are trading bar closes, so if we are trading real-time, there should be no problem.   
The only problem arises with manual backtesting - because results could look on charts better then actualy are.   
  
Interesting thing is that the same problem arises if you will plot vertical line on you chart in higher TF and when you move to the lower TF, the vertical line is not in the right place too (its moved left too, to the opening time, but the stochastic is computed at closing time, so in backtesting its looks like the stochastic made the signal couple of bars earlier. Again, try it on charts and wach the closing prices.  
  
But anyway, even if we look on charts the right way (= always shifting the higher TF lines in your mind to the right), the MTF strategy is very profitable and interesting, especially if you take only the best signals = higher TF move first, all lines goes in the same way, only 15min stoch makes pullback and then turns back.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)

Have found a very good use for stochs. I just discovered this MTF thread, so I thought i'd share it here.   
  
Pretty simple. I use the daily as my main trend gauge. Price must be trading below 50 SMA and well, MA should be trending downward approx 20 degrees (If you have to think hard to yourself if it is trending, then its not. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) )   
  
When 4 hour and 1hour stochs is overbought, almost certainly, it's a great place to start hunting for shorts.

Max that template is long gone, I play with templates all the time. Anyway the MTF stoch v2.0 is on post 1436 complements of CindyXXXX. what you do is open navigator and drag the indicator onto the chart. Set it up as to what TF and the parameters. I usually set %D to "none" for color. Then, drag another copy of that same indicator into the existing stoch window, then set that one up for another time frame. Do this for the 15, 30, 1 and h4 making each a different color and you're done. The indicator on the right corner is called "stoch bars" (attached).

HI Max - You will never be able to see a 1 hour stoch on a 4 hour chart. You can only view the 1 hour stoch on a 1 hour or lower TF because obviously the 60 min closes can be viewed only on them. There are 4 60 min closes in one 4 hr bar so thats why it is impossible.
